captions.text:
A few months ago the headlines were dominated
by the fact that physicists think they found

the Higgs boson.  Well, the media said, this
is a great discovery, but what do you mean

you think you found the Higgs boson?  Well,
to within five standard deviations, yes, we

think we found the Higgs boson.  And the
media said, what do you mean by that? Well

I would have answered the question differently. 
I would have said, "With 99.9999% confidence,

we have bagged the Higgs boson.  If you are
an odds maker in Las Vegas, and the bets are

that you are 99.9999% confident that you have
it, then yes, you have it." So experimental

data is not ironclad.  You have a bell-shaped
curve of information, a bell-shaped curve

where the data indicates that you're sitting
right here on the top of the bell-shaped curve,

but as you go away from the bell-shaped curve,
you undergo one standard deviation, two standard

deviations, three standard deviations… and
here we have five standard deviations of proof.

So in physics we use that as the gold standard:
if you can say you found something within

five standard deviations, then it means that,
within 99.9999% accuracy, you have actually

found it.  Most people would say, of course
you have found it. The Higgs boson is important

not just because it gives particles mass. 
That's how the media played it, and people

say, well, so what; ten billion dollars for
another god darn subatomic particle that gives

us mass; what's the big deal; why call it
the God particle; why say that it's one of

the great achievements of modern science? 
Well, you have to understand something: we

physicists squirm when we hear "God particle,"
but, you see, there is some truth to the name

"the God particle" because the Bible says
that God set the universe into motion.  That's

what God did in Genesis, chapter one, verse
one.  However, we physicists say that the

universe was created in a big bang 13.7 billion
years ago.  But then the question is, why

did it bang?  What set off the bang?  We
don't know.  It's a big mystery.  Well,

the answer is a Higgs-like boson set off the
Big Bang.  It put the bang in the Big Bang.

See, the purpose of Higgs bosons—and there
is more than one—the purpose of the Higgs

boson is to break a symmetry.  And when you
break symmetries like the symmetry of the

universe, then you get big bangs.  So what
is the Higgs boson?  The Higgs boson is a

fuse.  It's a match.  It's the spark that
set off the Big Bang.  It put the bang in
the Big Bang.

title: Michio Kaku: What Put the Bang in the Big Bang?

comments.text:
I am so tired of hearing the "something can't come from nothing" rant, that 
I feel like i really need to clear this shit up.

The term "something coming from nothing" is misinterpreted by the vast 
majority. Nothing is to be considered as a state of absolute zero, a 
balance point of energy, like balancing something on the edge of a knifes 
blade, with an inclination of zero degrees. Like the object you are 
balancing on the knifes edge, the singularity which was the state of our 
universe before the Big Bang, is a balance of energy; positive energy on 
one side, negative energy on the other (don't take it all literally since 
it's an analogy). The positive and negative states of energy are 
represented in matter and antimatter, and we have observed what happens 
when matter and antimatter collide with each other, and the result is that 
they both pop out of existence, and we have also observed matter and 
antimatter pop into existence. It is very probable that if you add up all 
the positive and negative energy in our universe, it would reveal that it 
would all amount to an amount of energy equal to zero. This means that we 
are basically still living in a universe which you could consider to be 
"nothing" - hence the laws of energy balance are not violated, and it is 
possible to explain how the universe came into existence.

Now, let's clear up a few more misconceptions which I have noticed in the 
comment section to this video.
- The Big Bang was in fact not a bang, it produced no sound and it was not 
an explosion, it was merely a rapid expansion.
- Time did not exist before the Big Bang, time is not a steady unit, it is 
merely a term used to describe the way the human brain percieve different 
progressions and different variations in states of matter in the universe. 
The term "time" is not a single unit - space and time are one and the same, 
hence the term spacetime, and both time and space can be warped and 
distorted (time can change speed, space can change shape), which we can 
observe by looking at galaxies in telescopes, where light is warped around 
for instance a black hole.
- The Higgs Boson is not what gives particles mass. The Higgs Boson is 
merely an exitation of the Higgs Field, and the mass of a particle is 
determined by how much it interacts with the Higgs Field. The boson is - as 
I just mentioned - an exitation of the Higgs Field, and it is the only part 
of the field that is currently measureable, which means that the discovery 
of the Higgs Boson confirms the existence of the Higgs Field, which 
confirmes the standard model, and our theory on why and how particles have 
mass.

This comment turned out to much longer than I intended it to be, but I hope 
it answered some of your questions, and made you consider new things. :)﻿
comments.author: Mads Leegaard (DukTape)

comments.text:
Higgs was discovered at first to 5 Sigma. 5 Sigma in Science is the point 
we "Declare" something was discovered, simply because the data would be 
99.99978% confirmed, leaving a 1 in million chance it was a fluke. Going 
further, it was strengthened to 7 sigma, or 99.99999999999743% confirmed. 
Nothing is ever 100%. I'm going with CERN on this one, and 1 in 300 million 
chance of a fluke is quite silly to fathom, whether it could happen or not.
comments.author: JamesCizuz

comments.text:
Another nail in the coffin is you talk about real as opposed to tested 
mathematical formulas. That is more philosophy then Science, as it would 
require a Theory of Everything, or at least a GUT to explain. So why even 
bring it up? Oh yeah, you're pulling stuff out of your ass. 3. Higgs was 
discovered through decay chain. Certain decay modes indicate a Higgs was 
discovered. 5 Sigma requires a "1 in a million chance" the results are 
wrong. 7 sigma is 1 in 300 million.
comments.author: JamesCizuz

comments.text:
What is charge? A physical property, in the case of Electromagnetic Charge 
particles exchange virtual bosons known as Photons, this exchange causes a 
momentum shift; the type of momentum shift determines if it's attractive, 
or repulsive. You also just showed you know nothing. The Standard Model is 
NOT based on GR/SR. GR/SR speak of Gravity, the Standard Model was made to 
explain Electromagnetic, Weak, and Strong interactions.
comments.author: JamesCizuz

comments.text:
Mass is in most cases binding energy. Higgs Field only accounts for mass of 
most elementary particles. For an example, Protons mass, 98% of it comes 
from binding energy keeping the Gluons together. Mass is a form of energy. 
What's there not to get?
comments.author: JamesCizuz

comments.text:
To put it further into perspective, most particles that have mass, at least 
mass given by the Higgs Field are technically still "Massless" in a sense. 
Electron A is "Massless" as is Electron B. Or Top Quark A and B, etc etc. 
You can imagine an excitation of the Electron Field moving at C, decaying, 
then moving in a random direction becoming localized, Electron A and B 
effectively become the Electron. This decaying holds a certain amount of 
binding energy. That's mass.
comments.author: JamesCizuz

comments.text:
1. Mass is a funny concept. Did you know an Electron is "Two particles" in 
a sense, Electron A and Electron B. Long story short, Electron A decays 
into Electron B and vice versa, this decay is due to coupling with the 
Higgs Field. Electron A exists briefly, decays to Electron B, and vice 
versa extremely fast. This collective entity we call the Electron. In a Nut 
Shell Mass is just a particle quickly decaying between two "modes". All 
particles with mass do this. Top Quark A and B, etc etc.
comments.author: JamesCizuz

comments.text:
It bothers me to no end, because the Higgs Boson doesn't even give mass. 
The Higgs Field does, the Higgs Boson is an excitation. It's to hard to 
detect the Higgs Field, so we detect an excitation in it, or particle known 
as the Higgs Boson to infer there is the Higgs Field as well. Even then, 
the Higgs Field only gives SOME things mass, yet michio treats it like it's 
the fucking end all be all. I really loved him, want to see him crash and 
burn now.
comments.author: JamesCizuz

comments.text:
That said, he said a higgs-like boson. This is also wrong, we don't know 
what caused the Big Bang. It was most likely symmetry breaking, symmetry 
breaks in a lot of different areas caused by particles, fields and other 
such events. He simplified to the point of saying a higgs-like boson when 
the higgs boson doesn't even give mass to begin with. Higgs Field does. 
Symmetry breaking is a standard theory for the big bang however, what 
caused it is unknown. It's not god though.
comments.author: JamesCizuz

comments.text:
Neither do Scientists. Michio has a tendency to... Well he's not really 
that respected in the higher field do to his extreme simplifications and 
outright... Wrong explanations. An example is Higgs Boson does not give 
mass. It's a excitation of the higgs field which gives a TYPE of mass to 
certain particles. Only about 1% of mass comes from the higgs in a proton 
for example.
comments.author: JamesCizuz

comments.text:
1. The Higgs Boson does not impart mass to a particle. It is an excitation 
of the higgs field, which imparts mass to a particle. 2. The Standard Model 
fails as much as GR/SR, QM, QCD or any other theories as to say it doesn't 
fail. It's well tested, gives good results, we know it's not the final 
story, which is why you build/change and modify over time to get the real 
story. 3. Nothing in science is fact. It's all extremely high 
probabilities. Higgs was discovered to 7 sigma.
comments.author: JamesCizuz

comments.text:
One of the greatest difficulties of science is that at certain levels, it 
ceases to be logical for our minds anyway, because what we perceive as 
logical is what we can actually see and understand and learn from 
empirically. For theoretical physics and many other abstract subjects, 
sometimes it is necessary to understand things from a statistical point of 
view, which is like a secondary representation of direct interaction with 
data, IMO.

comments.text:
The "Big Bang" is a derogatory term said by the astronomer Fred Hoyle, who 
was opposing the idea of the... Big Bang and the proponents of the steady 
state universe (which happens to be wrong and now obsolete). But the name 
is catchy and obviously we still use it, no matter how wrong it is - it was 
not "Big", it was infinitely small and nothing "Banged" since there was 
nowhere to bang. "biblical evidence" - there's no shred of evidence to 
support the bible, using it as an evidence is absurd.
